title: Chinese Government donates 5 million RMB for disaster relief in Cambodia following the 2000 floods
description: In the second half of 2000, Cambodia suffered from the worst flooding in over 70 years. In response, on 7 December 2000, officials representing the Chinese Government of the Government of Cambodia signed an exchange of notes committing 5 million RMB for unspecified relief goods.  This is the second donation from the Chinese Government for disaster relief in Cambodia following the 2000 floods. The first donation is captured in Project #32065.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates 5 million RMB for disaster relief in Cambodia following the 2000 floods

# Description
In the second half of 2000, Cambodia suffered from the worst flooding in over 70 years. In response, on 7 December 2000, officials representing the Chinese Government of the Government of Cambodia signed an exchange of notes committing 5 million RMB for unspecified relief goods.  This is the second donation from the Chinese Government for disaster relief in Cambodia following the 2000 floods. The first donation is captured in Project #32065.
justification: Project is focused on disaster relief and humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: 5 million RMB donation for unspecified relief goods following floods, humanitarian focus

title: China Eximbank provides $15.5 million export seller's credit for 12MW Kirirom I Hydropower Plant Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#32202)
description: On December 9, 2000, China Eximbank provided a $15.5 million export seller's credit to China Electric Power Technology Import & Export Corporation (CETIC) for the 12MW Kirirom I Hydropower Plant Rehabilitation Project. The credit was disbursed in an RMB 91.5 million tranche and a $4.5 million tranche. The purpose of this $19.24 million project was to rehabilitate the Kirirom I Hydropower Plant, which is located in the Kirirom National Park of Koh Kong Province.  The Kirirom I Hydropower Plant is linked to Phnom Penh by a 120 km long, 115kV transmission line. It supplies electricity to Kampong Speu Province and Phnom Penh. The Kirirom I Hydropower Plant was originally built in 1968 with support from Yugoslavia. In 1975, under the Khmer Rouge regime, the power plant fell into disrepair and electricity production stopped.  In 1999, China Electric Power Technology Import & Export Corporation (CETIC) — a Chinese state-owned enterprise — was contracted to re-build the power plant at a cost of $24 million under a 30-year build-operate-transfer (BOT) agreement. CETIC then signed a power purchase agreement (PPA) with Electricité du Cambodge (EDC) on July 28, 2000. The rehabilitation project commenced on April 2, 2001. This project was completed and plant put into operation on May 29, 2002. The total installed capacity of the rehabilitated plant was 12,000 kilowatts, and its average annual power generation is 53 million kilowatt-hours. The plant generated about 46.5GWh, 43.3GWh and 44.4GWh in 2007, 2008 and 2009, respectively. Under the terms of the BOT agreement, CETIC agreed to operate the plant for 30 years before handing it over to the Government Cambodia.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 基里隆I号水电站.2. Under the terms of the BOT agreement, the Government of Cambodia granted CETIC the exclusive rights to (a) develop, design, finance, rehabilitate, construct, own, operate, maintain, and manage the existing and newly constructed facilities of the Kirirom 1 hydropower plant with a capacity of 12 MW; (b) develop, design, finance, and construct transmission facilities and then transfer the plant to EDC after completion of commission; and (c) sell to EDC all generated electricity from Kirirom under a 30-year PPA.3. CETIC was also involved in a subsequent, China Eximbank-financed expansion of the same power plant (see Project ID#32202).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $15.5 million export seller's credit for 12MW Kirirom I Hydropower Plant Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#32202)

# Description
On December 9, 2000, China Eximbank provided a $15.5 million export seller's credit to China Electric Power Technology Import & Export Corporation (CETIC) for the 12MW Kirirom I Hydropower Plant Rehabilitation Project. The credit was disbursed in an RMB 91.5 million tranche and a $4.5 million tranche. The purpose of this $19.24 million project was to rehabilitate the Kirirom I Hydropower Plant, which is located in the Kirirom National Park of Koh Kong Province.  The Kirirom I Hydropower Plant is linked to Phnom Penh by a 120 km long, 115kV transmission line. It supplies electricity to Kampong Speu Province and Phnom Penh. The Kirirom I Hydropower Plant was originally built in 1968 with support from Yugoslavia. In 1975, under the Khmer Rouge regime, the power plant fell into disrepair and electricity production stopped.  In 1999, China Electric Power Technology Import & Export Corporation (CETIC) — a Chinese state-owned enterprise — was contracted to re-build the power plant at a cost of $24 million under a 30-year build-operate-transfer (BOT) agreement. CETIC then signed a power purchase agreement (PPA) with Electricité du Cambodge (EDC) on July 28, 2000. The rehabilitation project commenced on April 2, 2001. This project was completed and plant put into operation on May 29, 2002. The total installed capacity of the rehabilitated plant was 12,000 kilowatts, and its average annual power generation is 53 million kilowatt-hours. The plant generated about 46.5GWh, 43.3GWh and 44.4GWh in 2007, 2008 and 2009, respectively. Under the terms of the BOT agreement, CETIC agreed to operate the plant for 30 years before handing it over to the Government Cambodia.
justification: Primary purpose is rehabilitation and operation of a hydropower plant, a renewable energy source
evidence: 12MW Kirirom I Hydropower Plant rehabilitation, renewable energy focus, 12,000 kilowatts installed capacity, average annual power generation of 53 million kilowatt-hours

title: 10th Chinese medical team sent to Cameroon hospitals in 2000
description: The 10th medical team of 28 members worked at the new Chinese-aided Yaounde Gynaeco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital, as well as the Mbalmayo District Hospital and Guider District Hospital, from 2000 to 2002. China has been sending medical teams to Cameroon every two years since 1975. Shanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
10th Chinese medical team sent to Cameroon hospitals in 2000

# Description
The 10th medical team of 28 members worked at the new Chinese-aided Yaounde Gynaeco-Obstetric and Pediatric Hospital, as well as the Mbalmayo District Hospital and Guider District Hospital, from 2000 to 2002. China has been sending medical teams to Cameroon every two years since 1975. Shanxi Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment, hospital operations, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Government dispatches 9th Chinese medical team to the Friendship Hospital in Bangui
description: The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Central African Republic every two years since 1978 (except for a 7-year pause that took place for political reasons). Zhejiang Province has been responsible for sending the teams. In 2000, the Chinese Government dispatched the 9th medical team to the Central African Republic.  The team was stationed at the Friendship Hospital (Hôpital de l'Amitié), which was built with funding from the Chinese Government during the 1980s, in the capital city of Bangui. The team completed its term of service between August 2000 and August 2002. It treated patients as well as provided medical technology training to local doctors in the area.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 9th Chinese medical team to the Friendship Hospital in Bangui

# Description
The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Central African Republic every two years since 1978 (except for a 7-year pause that took place for political reasons). Zhejiang Province has been responsible for sending the teams. In 2000, the Chinese Government dispatched the 9th medical team to the Central African Republic.  The team was stationed at the Friendship Hospital (Hôpital de l'Amitié), which was built with funding from the Chinese Government during the 1980s, in the capital city of Bangui. The team completed its term of service between August 2000 and August 2002. It treated patients as well as provided medical technology training to local doctors in the area.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services and medical training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment, patient treatment, medical technology training

title: Chinese Government provides grant worth 5.43 million euros for Radio and Television Center Construction and Equipping Project
description: On or around the year 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Comoros signed a grant agreement for the Radio and Television Center Construction and Equipping Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce was the source of funding and it committed 5.43 million euros (or 2.675 billion Comorian francs) in total. The project involved the construction of a building for the National Broadcasting and Television Center — called l'Office de Radio et Télévision des Comores (ORTC) — in the town of Voidjou. It also involved the provision and installation of radio and TV broadcasting equipment.   China Radio and TV International Architectural Design Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project design and China Radio and Television International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (CRTV or 中国广播电视国际经济技术合作总公司) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  A foundation laying ceremony took place on August 4, 1999. Then, on May 26, 2002, a friendship tree planting ceremony at the project site took place. The project passed final MOFCOM inspection on April 14, 2005. ORTC began broadcasting on the analogue terrestrial network on April 7, 2006 at 5PM. Then, on May 3, 2006, a formal ORTC inauguration ceremony took place.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 广播电视大楼 or 科摩罗国家广播电视台 or 援科摩罗国家广播电视中心 or 摩罗国家广播电视大楼 or 科摩罗广电中心大楼设计项目 or 援科摩罗广播电视中心项目 or 科摩罗国家电视中心 or 广电设备维修项目 or 科摩罗广电设备项目 or 援科摩罗广电设备项目. The French project title is  l'Office de Radio et Télévision des Comores (ORTC) or Le bâtiment abritant la radio et télévision nationale or Construction du bâtiment abritant la radio et la télévision nationale et prise en charge de son équipement.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant worth 5.43 million euros for Radio and Television Center Construction and Equipping Project

# Description
On or around the year 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Comoros signed a grant agreement for the Radio and Television Center Construction and Equipping Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce was the source of funding and it committed 5.43 million euros (or 2.675 billion Comorian francs) in total. The project involved the construction of a building for the National Broadcasting and Television Center — called l'Office de Radio et Télévision des Comores (ORTC) — in the town of Voidjou. It also involved the provision and installation of radio and TV broadcasting equipment.   China Radio and TV International Architectural Design Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project design and China Radio and Television International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (CRTV or 中国广播电视国际经济技术合作总公司) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.  A foundation laying ceremony took place on August 4, 1999. Then, on May 26, 2002, a friendship tree planting ceremony at the project site took place. The project passed final MOFCOM inspection on April 14, 2005. ORTC began broadcasting on the analogue terrestrial network on April 7, 2006 at 5PM. Then, on May 3, 2006, a formal ORTC inauguration ceremony took place.
justification: Project focuses on communications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of broadcasting center and installation of radio/TV equipment, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government dispatches 16th medical team to Makélékélé Reference Hospital and Talangaï Hospital
description: Since 1967, the Chinese Government has been dispatching medical teams to the Republic of Congo every two years. Tianjin City is responsible for sending the teams. On December 28, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Congo signed letters of exchange, dispatching the 16th Chinese medical team to the Republic of Congo  [第16批援刚（布）医疗队].   The 26-member team was stationed at Makélékélé Reference Hospital (Hôpital de Makélékélé) and Talangaï Hospital (Hôpital De Talangaï) in the capital city of Brazzaville. It completed its term of service between December 15, 2000 and December 16, 2002.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 16th medical team to Makélékélé Reference Hospital and Talangaï Hospital

# Description
Since 1967, the Chinese Government has been dispatching medical teams to the Republic of Congo every two years. Tianjin City is responsible for sending the teams. On December 28, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Congo signed letters of exchange, dispatching the 16th Chinese medical team to the Republic of Congo  [第16批援刚（布）医疗队].   The 26-member team was stationed at Makélékélé Reference Hospital (Hôpital de Makélékélé) and Talangaï Hospital (Hôpital De Talangaï) in the capital city of Brazzaville. It completed its term of service between December 15, 2000 and December 16, 2002.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services and medical support, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 2 million grant for Parliament Building Maintenance Project
description: In January 2000, the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China provided an RMB 2 million grant to the Republic of Congo's Transitional Council for the Parliament Building Maintenance Project. This project involved the maintenance of air-conditioning units and elevators in the Parliament Building (Palais des Congrès) in the capital city of Brazzaville.   This building was constructed with financial support from the Chinese Government in the 1980s. On May 5, 2005, China’s Ambassador to the Republic of Congo and the Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and French-speaking Affairs of the Republic of Congo Daniel OWASSA signed the project handover certificate.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 刚果议会大厦空调机组及电梯的维修.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 2 million grant for Parliament Building Maintenance Project

# Description
In January 2000, the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China provided an RMB 2 million grant to the Republic of Congo's Transitional Council for the Parliament Building Maintenance Project. This project involved the maintenance of air-conditioning units and elevators in the Parliament Building (Palais des Congrès) in the capital city of Brazzaville.   This building was constructed with financial support from the Chinese Government in the 1980s. On May 5, 2005, China’s Ambassador to the Republic of Congo and the Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and French-speaking Affairs of the Republic of Congo Daniel OWASSA signed the project handover certificate.
justification: Project involves maintenance of existing government building infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Maintenance of air-conditioning units and elevators in Parliament Building, categorized under social infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 31.2 million grant for 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant Rehabilitation Project
description: On March 5, 2000 and March 8, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Congo signed letters of exchange for the 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant Rehabilitation Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of grant funding for this project and it reportedly committed RMB 31,265,400 in total. This project involved the rehabilitation of the 74 MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant. More specifically, it involved the rehabilitation of four sets of hydroelectric power generating units, four main valves, 15 main transformer stations, nearly 500 km of high voltage power transmission lines, 56 circuit breakers and 250 pieces of auxiliary electromechanical equipment. Damage to the transmission network was preventing its power from reaching Brazzaville, which was relying on power from the Inga plants in the Democratic Republic of Congo.   The 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant is located on the Bouenza River. It was originally built by Chinese technicians and commissioned in 1979 to supply energy to Pointe-Noire. It is the main source of power to the south of the country. The energy produced by the power plant is injected into the transmission network, which includes the 110 kV transformer substations at Bouenza Il, Nkayi and Loudima, and the 35 kV transformer substations at Loutété, Madingou and Dolisie.   On July 24, 2001, the Republic of Congo sent a team to China to review the project design documents. Then, on April 4, 2002, a delegation headed by the Secretary General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation went to China to sign a construction contract. Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on October 10, 2003 and the project was completed on June 15, 2007.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Bouenza Hydropower Station Rehabilitation Project. The Chinese project title is 援布昂扎水电站项目 or 中国援刚果（布）布昂扎水电站维修项目 or 刚果（布）布昂扎水电站维修项目. The French project title is Révision générale de la centrale hydroélectrique de Moukoukoulou or Le barrage de Moukoukoulou or La centrale hydroélectrique de Moukoulou de la Bouenza.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 31.2 million grant for 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant Rehabilitation Project

# Description
On March 5, 2000 and March 8, 2000, the Chinese Government and the Republic of Congo signed letters of exchange for the 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant Rehabilitation Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of grant funding for this project and it reportedly committed RMB 31,265,400 in total. This project involved the rehabilitation of the 74 MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant. More specifically, it involved the rehabilitation of four sets of hydroelectric power generating units, four main valves, 15 main transformer stations, nearly 500 km of high voltage power transmission lines, 56 circuit breakers and 250 pieces of auxiliary electromechanical equipment. Damage to the transmission network was preventing its power from reaching Brazzaville, which was relying on power from the Inga plants in the Democratic Republic of Congo.   The 74MW Moukoukoulou Hydroelectric Power Plant is located on the Bouenza River. It was originally built by Chinese technicians and commissioned in 1979 to supply energy to Pointe-Noire. It is the main source of power to the south of the country. The energy produced by the power plant is injected into the transmission network, which includes the 110 kV transformer substations at Bouenza Il, Nkayi and Loudima, and the 35 kV transformer substations at Loutété, Madingou and Dolisie.   On July 24, 2001, the Republic of Congo sent a team to China to review the project design documents. Then, on April 4, 2002, a delegation headed by the Secretary General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation went to China to sign a construction contract. Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on October 10, 2003 and the project was completed on June 15, 2007.
justification: Primary purpose is rehabilitation of a hydroelectric power plant, a renewable energy source
evidence: 74MW hydroelectric power plant rehabilitation, focus on renewable energy generation and transmission infrastructure

title: Chinese Government provides CFA 150 million grant for population census and pre-electoral operations
description: In December 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed a grant agreement worth CFA 150 million to facilitate the implementation of a population census and thereby support pre-electoral operations.

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Alphonse Massamba-Debat Stadium Rehabilitation Project (Linked to projects #57779 and #32011)
description: In December 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed a grant agreement worth CFA 1.5 billion for the Alphonse Massamba-Debat Stadium Rehabilitation Project. This project involved the rehabilitation of the Alphonse Massamba-Debat stadium in the capital city of Brazzaville. More specifically, the project sought to increase the seating capacity of the stadium from 17,500 to 20,000 and to construct two VIP lounges, a hotel with ten rooms, a restaurant, modern locker rooms, and facilities for volleyball, handball, and basketball.   Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd. (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for implementation of the project. Rehabilitation works began on January 15, 2001, and the newly-renovated stadium was officially inaugurated on February 19, 2002.   The French project title is Le projet de réhabilitation du stade de football Alphonse Massamba Débat or Le projet de réhabilitation du stade de football Alphonse Massamba-Débat. The Chinese project title is 马桑巴·代巴体育场技术合作项目 or 中国援刚果（布）马桑巴•代巴体育场维修项目.
staff_comments: 1. The article 'Congo: China announces US $5.7 million grant for reconstruction' states that the transaction amount of the project is CFA 1.5 billion. However, since no official documents verify the amount, AidData did not add a transaction amount for the project. 2. The project is marked by MOFCOM as Chinese Aid. Based on this, AidData set the flow type as grant and set the flow class as ODA-like.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Alphonse Massamba-Debat Stadium Rehabilitation Project (Linked to projects #57779 and #32011)

# Description
In December 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Republic of Congo signed a grant agreement worth CFA 1.5 billion for the Alphonse Massamba-Debat Stadium Rehabilitation Project. This project involved the rehabilitation of the Alphonse Massamba-Debat stadium in the capital city of Brazzaville. More specifically, the project sought to increase the seating capacity of the stadium from 17,500 to 20,000 and to construct two VIP lounges, a hotel with ten rooms, a restaurant, modern locker rooms, and facilities for volleyball, handball, and basketball.   Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co., Ltd. (WIETC) was the contractor responsible for implementation of the project. Rehabilitation works began on January 15, 2001, and the newly-renovated stadium was officially inaugurated on February 19, 2002.   The French project title is Le projet de réhabilitation du stade de football Alphonse Massamba Débat or Le projet de réhabilitation du stade de football Alphonse Massamba-Débat. The Chinese project title is 马桑巴·代巴体育场技术合作项目 or 中国援刚果（布）马桑巴•代巴体育场维修项目.
justification: Project focuses on stadium rehabilitation and sports facility development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Stadium rehabilitation, increased seating capacity, construction of sports facilities and auxiliary buildings
